study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of abscisic acid (ABA) and GR24 on tomato fruit ripening, ethylene emission, carotenoid biosynthesis, ABA metabolism, and chromoplast development.
results_summary: GR24 significantly accelerated ripening in yft3 tomatoes and enhanced color development in wild-type M82, while ABA had a moderate effect. Both treatments increased carotenoid content and altered gene expression related to ethylene and carotenoid biosynthesis, with GR24 also promoting chromoplast differentiation.
population_specificity: yft3 and wild-type (WT cv. M82) tomato fruits at 35, 47, and 54 days post-anthesis (dpa).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a carvacrol-based micro-emulsion cleaner could enhance the safety and shelf-life of cherry tomatoes by inhibiting microbial growth and pesticide residues.
results_summary: The cleaner demonstrated strong antibacterial and antifungal activity, reduced pesticide residues by 76-91%, and effectively preserved cherry tomatoes' color and hardness during storage at 4°C. It also remained stable for at least 3 months at room temperature.
population_specificity: Cherry tomatoes (food industry application).
effective_dosage: 67 mg/mL of carvacrol in the formulated cleaner.
study_duration: Storage at 4°C (specific intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how gibberellin 3 (GA3) and other plant hormones regulate cell wall remodeling and plant height in tomatoes via the gene SlXTH19.
results_summary: GA3 treatment increased tomato plant height and SlXTH19 expression, enhancing cell wall integrity through larger cell dimensions and higher lignin, cellulose, and hemicellulose content. Conversely, ETH and NAA treatments suppressed plant height and SlXTH19 expression, revealing competitive hormonal regulation of cell wall remodeling.
population_specificity: Tomato plants (Solanum lycopersicum L.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the interactive effects of different irrigation levels and fertilizer application patterns on greenhouse tomato growth, yield, and resource use efficiency in arid regions.
results_summary: Increased irrigation improved plant growth, nitrogen uptake, and yield, with the I1C1 treatment achieving the highest yield under sufficient irrigation. The I2C1 treatment balanced yield with improved water use efficiency and nitrogen uptake, making it optimal for water-limited conditions.
population_specificity: Greenhouse tomatoes in arid regions (China).
effective_dosage: Three irrigation levels (I1: 90-100% field capacity, I2: 72-80% field capacity, I3: 54-60% field capacity) and four fertilizer treatments (C1: combined soluble organic and chemical fertilizer, C2: soluble chemical fertilizer only, C3: sheep manure and chemical fertilizer, C4: soluble organic fertilizer only).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of hot water treatment (HWT) and high-temperature ethylene (HTE) exposure on the postharvest quality and antioxidant properties of mature green tomatoes.
results_summary: HWT increased β-carotene levels and antioxidant capacity while preserving color, whereas HTE delayed ripening, increased acidity, and reduced dry matter content. The study also developed a predictive model for color parameters with high accuracy.
population_specificity: Mature green tomatoes (MG).
effective_dosage: HWT at 50°C or 25°C for 5 min; HTE at 20°C, 30°C, or 35°C for 24, 48, or 72 h.
study_duration: Varies by treatment (5 min for HWT; 24-72 h for HTE).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of a whey protein concentrate (WPC) and egg white protein (EWP) biodegradable film modified by transglutaminase (TG) for food packaging, specifically its preservation effects on cherry tomatoes.
results_summary: The TG-modified WPC/EWP film improved mechanical and barrier properties, reduced cherry tomato weight loss during storage (from 14.2% to 10.8%), and maintained quality indicators like hardness, pH, and lycopene content.
population_specificity: Cherry tomatoes (no human subjects studied).
study_duration: Not specified (storage period implied but not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of bioengineered anthocyanin-enriched tomatoes in preventing and suppressing colorectal cancer (CRC) by enhancing dietary anthocyanin intake.
results_summary: The study found that anthocyanins from bioengineered tomatoes modulate transcription factors involved in CRC development, alter metabolic pathways, and reduce tumor-related inflammation, demonstrating promise in CRC prevention. Case studies showed successful bioengineering of tomatoes to boost anthocyanin levels.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on CRC prevention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of p-coumaric acid (p-CA) on postharvest cherry tomatoes, focusing on physiological metabolism and sensory quality during storage.
results_summary: p-CA treatment improved sensory quality, increased phenolic compounds and flavonoids, enhanced antioxidant capacities, and delayed fruit ripening by regulating key metabolic pathways. Transcriptomics revealed 782 differentially expressed genes, supporting p-CA's role in modulating fruit preservation mechanisms.
population_specificity: Breaker stage cherry tomatoes (postharvest).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of LED lighting on tomato cultivation and postharvest quality, focusing on photosynthesis, growth, production, and shelf life.
results_summary: Red-blue LED lighting enhanced photosynthesis, chlorophyll content, and tomato production, while blue LED lighting improved postharvest qualities like color retention, hardness, and shelf life. Future research may explore LED effects on phytochemical and nutritional content.
population_specificity: Tomato plants in controlled environments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of electron beam (EB) irradiation in delaying ripening, preventing spoilage, and extending the shelf life of postharvest tomatoes.
results_summary: EB irradiation reduced microbial contamination and decay, preserved key quality attributes (e.g., firmness, acidity), minimized weight loss, and delayed lycopene biosynthesis without affecting phenolic content or antioxidant activity. The treatment extended shelf life by 5-10 days, with thermoluminescence analysis being the most reliable detection method for doses exceeding 600 Gy.
population_specificity: Postharvest tomatoes (no specific cultivar mentioned).
effective_dosage: Doses exceeding 600 Gy (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether high-voltage electrostatic field (HVEF) treatment could extend the shelf life of tomatoes by preserving their physicochemical properties and bioactive compounds during storage.
results_summary: HVEF treatment (90-120 min) significantly mitigated quality degradation in tomatoes, including firmness, weight, color, and bioactive compounds, extending shelf life by 14-28 days compared to controls. The treatment also inhibited pectin-degrading enzyme activity, maintaining commercial value.
population_specificity: Harvested tomatoes stored at 4 °C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a phytosanitary cold treatment protocol to eliminate fruit fly species concealed inside cherry tomatoes without damaging the fruit.
results_summary: The study achieved complete disinfestation of fruit flies after 15 days of cold treatment at 1°C-1.5°C, eliminating over 80,000 treated third instar Z. cucurbitae in each tomato variety while retaining commercial fruit value.
population_specificity: Cherry tomatoes (Solanum lycopersicum var. cerasiforme) infested with fruit fly species (Bactrocera dorsalis, Zeugodacus cucurbitae, Zeugodacus tau).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fungal secondary metabolites from Trichoderma, when challenged by Fusarium, could serve as effective biostimulants to enhance tomato plant growth and induce systemic resistance against Fusarium.
results_summary: The study found that the induced Trichoderma metabolites (TF.ex) significantly inhibited Fusarium growth (68.33%), promoted tomato plant growth, and increased defense-related enzyme activity (superoxide dismutase by 33%, catalase by 2.5-fold). GC-MS analysis identified 13 unique compounds in TF.ex, with Methyl dihydrojasmonate as the major metabolite.
population_specificity: Tomato plants (no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: 50 μg mL-1 of TF.ex for seed dressing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the best planting time (April, May, or June) for summer tomato cultivation in a Korean semi-closed greenhouse to optimize light use efficiency and yield.
results_summary: Tomatoes planted in April showed the highest light use efficiency (42.9% higher) and yield (33.3% higher) compared to May and June plantings, with growth closest to the reproductive growth type.
population_specificity: Tomato plants grown in a semi-closed greenhouse in Korea.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (planting times: April, May, June 2022).
study_duration: Harvesting occurred from 65 to 265 days after planting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium fertilization ratios for maximizing yield and nutritional quality in greenhouse tomatoes.
results_summary: Different fertilizer ratios significantly affected tomato yield and quality, with potassium having the strongest impact on yield. The N2P2K1 treatment (197.28 kg hm-2 nitrogen, 88.75 kg hm-2 phosphorus, 229.80 kg hm-2 potassium) produced the highest nutritional quality and yield.
population_specificity: Greenhouse tomatoes in Jilin Province.
effective_dosage: Nitrogen (197.28 kg hm-2), phosphorus (88.75 kg hm-2), potassium (229.80 kg hm-2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of different red-blue light ratios and white light on radiation-use efficiency (RUE) and fruit biomass radiation-use efficiency (FBRUE) in dwarf tomatoes.
results_summary: Monochromatic red light reduced RUE and FBRUE, while higher blue light proportions improved these metrics. White light outperformed red-blue light combinations, increasing RUE and FBRUE, with cultivar-specific benefits in fruit quality and dry mass partitioning.
population_specificity: Dwarf tomato cultivars ('Micro-Tom' and 'Rejina').
effective_dosage: Photosynthetic photon flux density of 300 μmol m-2 s-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of chitosan sourced from mushrooms versus crustaceans in enhancing drought stress tolerance in tomato plants (cv. MicroTom).
results_summary: Drought stress reduced leaf water content, chlorophyll levels, and fruit yield, but chitosan application from either source improved these parameters and enhanced drought tolerance. The study suggests fungal chitosan may be a sustainable alternative to crustacean-derived chitosan.
population_specificity: Tomato plants (cv. MicroTom) exposed to drought stress.
study_duration: Two 14-day drought stress periods at vegetative and fruit set growth stages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal nutrient solution irrigation system for greenhouse tomatoes to maximize yield, quality, and water-fertilizer use efficiency.
results_summary: The study found that a nutrient solution application rate of 70% (T2) significantly improved water and fertilizer use efficiency and enhanced the nutritional and flavor quality of tomatoes without a significant yield reduction compared to higher application rates. The T3 treatment (80%) yielded the highest production but had lower efficiency metrics.
population_specificity: Greenhouse-grown tomatoes using coconut coir cultivation substrates.
effective_dosage: Nutrient solutions applied when substrate water content reached 60% (T1), 70% (T2), or 80% (T3), with upper limits set at 100%.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Beauveria bassiana Bb252, applied via root irrigation, affects the fitness, feeding behavior, and physiological changes of Bemisia tabaci on tomato plants.
results_summary: The study found that Beauveria bassiana Bb252 colonized tomato plant tissues temporarily (≤35 days) and significantly reduced the net reproductive rate (41.4%) and altered feeding behavior (reduced salivation, shortened phloem ingestion) of Bemisia tabaci. Additionally, whiteflies feeding on treated plants showed decreased hormone and amino acid levels.
population_specificity: Bemisia tabaci (whiteflies) on tomato plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antifungal effects of curcumin on Alternaria alternata and its pathogenicity in cherry tomato fruit.
results_summary: Curcumin significantly inhibited mycelial growth and spore germination of A. alternata, caused cell membrane damage, reduced black rot incidence in tomatoes, and upregulated defense-related genes while decreasing pathogenic enzyme activity.
population_specificity: Cherry tomato fruit infected with Alternaria alternata.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Raman spectroscopy could non-invasively detect strain-specific symptoms of tomato spotted wilt virus (TSWV) in differentially resistant tomato cultivars.
results_summary: The study found that Raman spectroscopy detected reductions in carotenoid-related vibrational peaks, confirmed by HPLC as a decrease in lutein concentration. PLS-DA analysis successfully differentiated strain-specific TSW symptoms across cultivars, suggesting RS as a promising tool for early TSW diagnosis.
population_specificity: Three differentially resistant tomato cultivars infected with four TSWV strains.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether heat-treated endophytic bacteria LSE01 (HTB) could enhance tomato plants' adaptation to high temperatures and drought conditions.
results_summary: HTB treatment increased tomato diameter and weight by 23.04% and 71.15% under stress, maintained yield, and boosted vitamin C, soluble sugars, and protein content. HTB enhanced stress resistance by improving photosynthetic pigment, proline levels, antioxidant activity, and gene expression related to drought and heat resistance.
population_specificity: Tomato plants under high-temperature and drought stress conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize the tomato PIP5K gene family and analyze their expression patterns under salt stress and in different tissues to understand their potential roles in plant growth, hormones, and stress responses.
results_summary: The study identified 21 PIP5K genes in tomatoes, classified into three groups, and found that some exhibited altered expression under salt stress and hormone treatments, suggesting their involvement in stress responses. SlPIP5K2, one of the genes, was localized to the membrane, providing insights into its potential biological function.
population_specificity: Tomato plants (specific variety not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether thermopriming could mitigate the impact of salt stress on tomato plant performance, yield, and fruit quality.
results_summary: Thermopriming triggered cross-tolerance to salinity, increasing phenol and flavonol accumulation in leaves and carotenoid and starch content in fruits, while sugars and acidity remained unaffected. Plant growth and yield initially slowed but later recovered.
population_specificity: Tomato transplants subjected to thermopriming and salt stress treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify features and outcomes of herb-induced liver injury (HILI) associated with Giloy use and assess its potential to unmask autoimmune hepatitis.
results_summary: The study found that Giloy was associated with acute hepatitis with autoimmune features, including hepatocyte and canalicular cholestasis, and could unmask autoimmune hepatitis in patients with silent chronic liver disease. Causality assessment indicated probable liver injury in 67.4% of cases.
population_specificity: 43 patients from 13 centers in India, predominantly female.
study_duration: Median time from initial consumption to symptom onset was 46 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the encapsulation of tomato-derived compounds (α-tomatine and tomatidine) in Solid Lipid Nanoparticles (SLN) to enhance their stability and bioavailability for potential anticancer applications.
results_summary: The study found that α-tomatine and tomatidine, when encapsulated in SLN, significantly reduced viability in neuroblastoma cancer cells (SH-SY5Y) without affecting normal olfactory ensheathing cells (OECs). Blank SLN showed no significant effects, indicating the potential of SLN for targeted delivery.
population_specificity: Olfactory Ensheathing Cells (OECs) and SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cancer cells.
effective_dosage: Free α-TM (0.25 µg/mL) and TD (0.50 µg/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a mixed enzymatic treatment (cutinase, cellulase, and pectinase) could improve pericarp permeability, enhance sensory quality, and increase nutrient content in cherry tomatoes for dried processing.
results_summary: The enzymatic treatment effectively improved pericarp permeability, increased lycopene (2.4-fold) and total polyphenol content (1.45-fold), and maintained sensory quality. Enzyme reuse (six times) achieved comparable results, reducing production costs.
population_specificity: Cherry tomatoes (no human or animal subjects mentioned).
effective_dosage: Different concentrations of mixed enzymes (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the accuracy of AquaCrop and DSSAT models in simulating tomato growth parameters (canopy coverage, soil water content, biomass, and yield) under different irrigation and mulching treatments in a greenhouse environment.
results_summary: The AquaCrop model showed higher simulation accuracy for canopy coverage, soil water changes under high water treatments, and lower relative errors for biomass, yield, and water use efficiency compared to the DSSAT model. The optimal treatment (S7, 0.8 Ep) yielded the highest tomato production (8.201 t/ha) and water use efficiency (2.79 kg/m³).
population_specificity: Greenhouse-grown tomatoes under drip irrigation with varying water and mulching treatments.
effective_dosage: Irrigation based on cumulative evaporation (0.5 Ep, 0.8 Ep, 0.9 Ep).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antifungal potential of dibenzylideneacetone (DBA) against Botrytis cinerea and its effectiveness in extending the shelf life of cherry tomatoes.
results_summary: DBA inhibited B. cinerea chitinase with an IC50 of 13.10 μg/mL, showed antifungal activity (MIC of 32 μg/mL), and extended cherry tomato shelf life by 2-fold in vivo.
population_specificity: Cherry tomatoes (in vivo study).
effective_dosage: MIC of 32 μg/mL against B. cinerea; EC50 values of 16.29 μg/mL (mycelial growth) and 14.64 μg/mL (spore germination).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different cooking processes (stir-frying, boiling) affect carotenoid release and gut microbiota composition during in vitro digestion of tomatoes.
results_summary: Stir-frying significantly increased lycopene and β-carotene release during digestion, while boiling enhanced carotenoid release during fermentation and promoted beneficial gut microbiota growth, potentially aiding obesity prevention. Boiling was more effective than raw or stir-fried tomatoes for colon health and carotenoid release.
population_specificity: In vitro simulated gastrointestinal digestion (no human subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how simulated gastrointestinal digestion affects the levels of bioactive compounds (polyphenols, flavonoids, carotenoids) and antioxidant capacity in cherry tomatoes.
results_summary: The study found that digestion significantly reduced the levels of total polyphenols, flavonoids, carotenoids, and antioxidant activity in cherry tomatoes, with decreases ranging from 34.95% to 78.38%. However, the degradation products may inhibit hepatoma cell growth and enhance intracellular antioxidant activity.
population_specificity: In vitro simulated digestion (no human or animal subjects).
study_duration: 120 minutes for stomach and small intestine digestion phases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of maize stover biochar on soil chemical properties, growth, and yield of tomatoes compared to inorganic fertilizers.
results_summary: Maize stover biochar improved soil chemical properties (pH, N, P, K, Ca, Mg) and, at 27.6 t ha-1, increased tomato fruit yield by 16.1% compared to inorganic fertilizer. However, lower biochar rates (3.5–13.8 t ha-1) resulted in lower plant growth and yield than inorganic fertilizer.
population_specificity: Tomato plants grown in Northern Uganda.
effective_dosage: Biochar applied at 3.5, 6.9, 13.8, and 27.6 t ha-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tomatidine and tomatine from tomatoes exert prophylactic and therapeutic antidepressant-like effects via mTORC1 activation in the medial prefrontal cortex.
results_summary: Tomatidine and tomatine reversed LPS-induced depression-like behaviors in mice, with effects mediated by mTORC1 activation in the mPFC. Both compounds showed efficacy in male and ovariectomized female mice, suggesting potential for treating depression.
population_specificity: Male mice and ovariectomized female mice (modeling menopause-associated depression).
study_duration: Not specified (administered before and after LPS challenge).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the concentration of imidacloprid in honeydew excreted by whiteflies feeding on tomato plants and assess its impact on whitefly populations.
results_summary: Imidacloprid reduced whitefly nymph and adult densities by 81.5% and 76.0% compared to controls at 21 days after treatment. The insecticide was detected in honeydew at concentrations of 180 ng/30 mL (1-4 DAT) and 218 ng/30 mL (5-8 DAT), suggesting potential secondary impacts on beneficial insects.
population_specificity: Whitefly-infested tomato plants.
effective_dosage: Labeled rate of imidacloprid applied to soil.
study_duration: 21 days post-treatment (with honeydew collection at 1-4 DAT and 5-8 DAT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of plasma-activated water (PAW) as a microbial decontamination wash for cherry tomatoes.
results_summary: PAW15 (15-minute plasma activation) achieved significant log reductions in Bacillus cereus, Salmonella sp., and Escherichia coli O157:H7 on cherry tomatoes, with no detected strains in the wash solution. Microbial counts remained below detection limits during 6-day storage at 25°C, and PAW15 showed no significant effect on RAW264.7 cell viability.
population_specificity: Cherry tomatoes inoculated with foodborne pathogens.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial effect and mechanism of ultrasound combined with Litsea cubeba essential oil nanoemulsion (LEON) on Salmonella in cherry tomatoes.
results_summary: LEON + US treatment significantly reduced Salmonella counts by 6.50 ± 0.20 log CFU/mL, exacerbated cell membrane damage, and induced apoptosis in bacterial cells. The combination altered cell morphology and increased membrane permeability.
population_specificity: Salmonella-contaminated cherry tomatoes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the differences in bacterial diversity and functions in tomato roots before and after transplanting in different cultivation media (soil and two substrates).
results_summary: The study found significant differences in bacterial β-diversity among the three cultivation media, with slight variations in species diversity but large differences in abundance at the genus level. After transplanting, the bacterial community structure and abundance in tomato roots resembled those in soil, and microbial function predictions suggested substrate environments had greater growth-promoting potential, while soil exhibited stronger antibacterial potential.
population_specificity: Tomato plants grown in greenhouse conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of green and red photo-selective filters on graft union formation, oxidative stress, and physiological development in grafted tomato plants.
results_summary: Green and red photo-selective filters increased ROS production initially but activated defense mechanisms, enhancing SOD and POD enzyme activity. Green netting improved cell proliferation, vascular tissue differentiation, and dry weight, suggesting a positive effect on graft union formation and overall growth.
population_specificity: Grafted tomato plants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the applicability and impact of PBAT mulch film on tomato growth, yield, and quality compared to PE film and non-mulching treatment in the arid region of Southern Xinjiang, China.
results_summary: PBAT film degraded 60.98% within 100 days, maintained soil temperature and humidity comparable to PE film during early growth stages, and did not significantly negatively affect tomato growth, yield, or quality. Tomato yield with PBAT was slightly lower (3.14%) than PE but significantly higher (63.38%) than non-mulching.
population_specificity: Tomato crops in Moyu County, Southern Xinjiang, China.
study_duration: 100 days (until substantial degradation of PBAT film)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to uncover the mechanism by which 5-aminolevunic acid (5-ALA) induces chromium (Cr) tolerance in tomato seedlings, focusing on nitric oxide (NO) signaling and antioxidant responses.
results_summary: The study found that foliar application of 5-ALA before Cr treatment improved tomato seedling growth, reduced oxidative stress markers, and enhanced antioxidant activity. The beneficial effects were mediated by nitrate reductase (NR)-generated NO, with Cr sequestration modulated by glutathione (GSH) and phytochelatins (PCs).
population_specificity: Tomato seedlings (specific cultivar not mentioned)
study_duration: 5-ALA applied for three days, fifteen days before Cr treatment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the postharvest preservation potential of three plant essential oils (Torreya grandis, Eriobotrya japonica, and Citrus medica) for cherry tomatoes by assessing their fungicidal activity against Botrytis cinerea.
results_summary: The study found that all three essential oils effectively inhibited the mycelial growth of B. cinerea, with Torreya grandis oil being the most effective at 200 µl/liter. Additionally, T. grandis oil treatment significantly increased phenolic content and enzyme activities in tomatoes by the seventh day.
population_specificity: Cherry tomatoes (Solanum lycopersicum) postharvest.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms of BABA-induced resistance (BABA-IR) in tomatoes against pathogens, particularly P. syringae pv. tomato DC3000, and compare its effects with other model plants.
results_summary: BABA significantly restricted pathogen growth in tomatoes, linked to the accumulation of pathogenesis-related protein transcripts and jasmonic acid signaling but not salicylic acid signaling. Resistance was reduced by L-Asp and L-Gln, with L-Asp's inhibition attributed to rapid metabolization to L-Gln rather than competition for AspRS binding.
population_specificity: Tomatoes (Solanum lycopersicum)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether long-term cover crops (CC) could improve soil health and subsequently reduce bacterial spot and anthracnose disease development in processing tomatoes while maintaining or increasing yield.
results_summary: The study found that cover crops generally led to similar or greater tomato yields and net revenue compared to no cover crops. In 2019, no cover crops resulted in earlier fruit maturity but higher disease incidence (defoliation, anthracnose) compared to radish and mixed cover crops. Disease incidence was low in 2020, limiting detectable treatment effects.
population_specificity: Processing tomatoes grown in Ridgetown, ON, under specific soil conditions with cover crop treatments.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (cover crop treatments were applied annually).
study_duration: 12 years (cover crops grown nine times over this period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of UV-C LED lighting systems (continuous and pulsed modes) for disinfecting fresh products, including tomatoes, by minimizing bacterial contamination in the supply chain.
results_summary: Mode 1 pulsed UV-C LED light showed the best germicidal effect (1.06–1.08 Log reduction at 25 mJ cm-²) and energy efficiency (11% reduction compared to continuous light). Both continuous light and Mode 1 demonstrated strong effective germicidal effects.
population_specificity: Fresh produce (including tomatoes) in the supply chain.
effective_dosage: UV-C doses of 5, 15, and 25 mJ cm-²; pulsed light frequencies of 500 Hz with duty cycles of 30%, 50%, and 80%.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether methyl salicylate (MeSA) pre-treatment could mitigate the loss of volatile compounds in tomatoes stored at low temperature and its effects on flavor-related gene expressions.
results_summary: MeSA pre-treatment effectively alleviated the loss of volatile compounds in low-temperature-stored tomatoes, particularly enhancing fatty acid pathway-related volatiles and up-regulating LOXC or LOXD gene expression. However, it had no significant effect on carotenoid or branched-chain amino acid pathway-related volatiles.
population_specificity: Tomato fruits stored at 10°C.
study_duration: 24 hours pre-treatment, storage duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antifungal activity of juniper essential oil (JEO) against gray mold (Botrytis cinerea) on cherry tomato fruit and explore its potential mechanisms.
results_summary: JEO effectively inhibited spore germination and mycelial growth of B. cinerea in a concentration-dependent manner, significantly reducing disease incidence and lesion diameters on cherry tomatoes. It also damaged fungal membranes, altered mycelial morphology, and modulated enzyme activities related to pathogenicity and antioxidant response.
population_specificity: Cherry tomato fruit (Solanum lycopersicum) infected with Botrytis cinerea.
study_duration: Observations made after 12 hours of treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the function of the STARD gene family in grapes and verify the role of VvSTARD5 in enhancing salt tolerance in transgenic tomatoes.
results_summary: The study found that overexpression of VvSTARD5 significantly increased salt tolerance in transgenic tomatoes, reducing relative electrical leakages and malondialdehyde content while enhancing proline levels and VvSTARD5 expression under NaCl treatment.
population_specificity: Transgenic tomato lines

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rosmarinic acid (RA) could improve thermotolerance in tomatoes under high-temperature stress and explore the underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: Exogenous RA application enhanced thermotolerance in tomatoes by boosting enzymatic antioxidant activity (APX, CAT, GR, DHAR), modulating redox homeostasis, and inducing heat-responsive transcription factors (HsfA2, WRKY) and heat shock proteins (HSPs). RNA-seq data indicated transcriptional regulation plays a role in RA-mediated thermotolerance.
population_specificity: Tomato plants subjected to high-temperature stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of PpNAC56 in enhancing heat resistance in transgenic tomato plants.
results_summary: The study found that PpNAC56-overexpressing tomato plants accumulated more osmoregulatory substances under high-temperature stress, improving heat resistance. PpNAC56 interacted with PpMIEL1 and activated the expression of PpHSP17.4 and PpSnRK2D, demonstrating its role in heat stress response.
population_specificity: Transgenic tomato plants (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an ethyl acetoacetate (EAA) wash in reducing bacterial contamination, specifically Salmonella enterica serovars and naturally occurring background flora, on tomatoes.
results_summary: The 8% EAA wash significantly reduced bacterial counts of externally added Salmonella serovars (1.5–3.4 log reduction) and naturally occurring background flora (2.1 log reduction). Tomato homogenate did not diminish the wash's efficacy, maintaining log reductions of 2.4–3.0 for tested serovars.
population_specificity: Tomatoes (no human or animal subjects mentioned).
study_duration: 2-hour incubation with tomato homogenate prior to wash application (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nanoscale sulfur (pristine and coated) could enhance tomato plant nutrition and suppress Fusarium oxysporum disease compared to bulk sulfur and ionic sulfate.
results_summary: Nanoscale sulfur (nS and cS) significantly reduced disease severity by 54-56%, improved sulfur accumulation, and activated a unique bioassimilation pathway, leading to increased disease resistance and plant immunity-related metabolites.
population_specificity: Tomato plants (Solanum lycopersicum) infested with Fusarium oxysporum in greenhouse experiments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial efficacy of chitosan-acid coatings on grape tomatoes to enhance safety and extend shelf-life.
results_summary: Both chitosan and chitosan+AIT coatings significantly reduced Salmonella, Listeria, and native microorganism populations, with chitosan+AIT showing greater initial efficacy. Coated tomatoes maintained better texture, color, and reduced water loss over 21 days compared to controls.
population_specificity: Whole grape tomatoes contaminated with nalidixic acid-resistant Salmonella, Listeria monocytogenes, and native microorganisms.
effective_dosage: Solution 1 (1% chitosan + 2% acetic, lactic, and levulinic acids); Solution 2 (Solution 1 + 2% AIT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of tomatoes and lycopene on prostate cancer risk using preclinical models to understand causal relationships and mechanisms.
results_summary: Tomatoes and lycopene demonstrated anti-prostate cancer activity in various rodent models, with earlier and sustained interventions showing greater efficacy. Lycopene was identified as one bioactive compound, but not the only one, contributing to these effects.
population_specificity: Rodent models (transplantable xenograft, chemically- and genetically-driven carcinogenesis, TRAMP model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the additive or synergistic effects of an enzyme-hydrolyzed animal protein biostimulant (Pepton) combined with low nitrogen priming on the production and quality of greenhouse tomatoes.
results_summary: Low nitrogen priming doubled fruit production and increased lycopene (90%) and vitamin E (40%) content. Pepton showed an additive effect, improving fruit production without compromising quality, likely due to increased cytokinins and photosynthetic pigments.
population_specificity: Greenhouse-grown tomato plants.
effective_dosage: Pepton at 4 kg/ha applied via ferti-irrigation.
study_duration: 2 months during the vegetative phase, with a 1-month recovery before fruit production.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of atmospheric cold plasma (ACP) treatment on fungal spores in sundried tomatoes and its effects on physicochemical properties and antioxidant activity.
results_summary: ACP treatment significantly reduced mesophilic aerobic bacteria and filamentous fungi, with sporicidal effects varying by species (88% non-germinated spores for A. rugulovalvus vs. 32% for A. niger). The treatment did not affect pH or water activity but increased lycopene content with longer exposure.
population_specificity: Sundried tomatoes contaminated with fungal spores (Aspergillus rugulovalvus and Aspergillus niger).
effective_dosage: 6 kV at 23 kHz, exposure times up to 30 minutes.
study_duration: Up to 30 minutes of ACP exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combination of UV-C irradiation and edible coating from dragon fruit mucilage could extend the shelf life and preserve the quality of cherry tomatoes.
results_summary: The hurdle treatment (UV-C + edible coating) extended shelf life by 21 days, reduced weight loss and color changes, inhibited microbial growth, and maintained higher levels of polyphenols, flavonoids, and ascorbic acid compared to stand-alone treatments.
population_specificity: Cherry tomatoes stored at 4 °C.
effective_dosage: Not specified (UV-C irradiation and edible coating application details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different maturity stages and post-harvest treatments (chilling and heating) affect the volatile profiles of ripe tomatoes.
results_summary: Chilling and heating suppressed overall volatile production, with chilling having a greater impact. Tomatoes harvested at the turning stage showed the least volatile suppression and developed abundant volatiles, making this stage the best harvest maturity recommendation.
population_specificity: Tomatoes at six maturity stages subjected to refrigerated storage (chilling) and blanching (heating) treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the viability of spent mushroom substrate as a nutrient source for tomato seedlings and develop an integrated tomato and mushroom co-production system.
results_summary: Tomato seedlings treated with substrate colonized by Agaricus bisporus showed superior root and aerial growth. The co-production system yielded high tomato (2.35 kg/plant pot) and mushroom (1.33 kg/plant pot) production, reduced tomato production time by 60 days, and prolonged mushroom production by 120 days.
population_specificity: Tomato seedlings and an integrated tomato-mushroom co-cultivation system.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Arabic gum coating, UV-C illumination, and their combinations on postharvest quality parameters of cocktail tomatoes.
results_summary: AG20 treatment showed the highest titratable acidity, total soluble solids, and fruit firmness, along with the lowest weight loss. It also maintained higher vitamin C content and reduced ethylene emissions and respiration rates compared to other treatments.
population_specificity: Mature green cocktail tomatoes (Solanum lycopersicum L. cv. Ipekce F1).
effective_dosage: 10% Arabic gum (AG10), 20% Arabic gum (AG20), 3.6 kJ m-2 UV-C illumination, and combinations of UV-C with AG10 or AG20.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of supplemental fumigation strategies (chloropicrin and 1,3-dichloropropene) in controlling root-knot nematodes and Fusarium wilt in commercial tomato fields.
results_summary: Deep-shank 1,3-D applications significantly reduced nematode recovery and both supplemental PIC and deep-shank 1,3-D reduced root-knot galling and Fusarium wilt incidence, though neither improved tomato yields. Laboratory experiments confirmed 1,3-D's fungicidal activity against Fusarium oxysporum.
population_specificity: Commercial tomato fields with a history of root-knot nematode and Fusarium wilt.
effective_dosage: Estimated field application rates of 1,3-D: 56.1, 93.5, 121.6, and 184.7 liters/ha for 75%, 90%, 95%, and 99% lethal doses, respectively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sulfur nanoparticles (SNPs) in managing Fusarium oxysporum infection in tomatoes and their potential as an eco-friendly crop protection strategy.
results_summary: Foliar application and seed treatment with SNPs significantly reduced pathogen infection, with 30 nm SNPs showing the best performance (47.6% decrease in disease incidence and 55.6% increase in shoot biomass). SNPs activated disease resistance pathways, upregulated related genes, and directly inactivated pathogens in tomato stems.
population_specificity: Tomato plants infected with Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. lycopersici in a greenhouse setting.
effective_dosage: 30-100 mg/L (30 and 100 nm SNPs), with 1 mg/plant of 30 nm SNPs being most effective.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different rootstocks and light spectra (red vs. mixed) affect tomato plant growth and yield under long photoperiod lighting (17 h vs. 23 h).
results_summary: Extending photoperiods to 23 h caused leaf chlorosis in all plants, but red light and 'Emperator' rootstock mitigated yield loss. Mixed light at 23 h reduced yield compared to 17 h treatments, while red light at 23 h maintained yield parity with 17 h treatments.
population_specificity: Greenhouse-grown tomato plants ('Trovanzo' grafted onto 'Emperator' or 'Kaiser' rootstocks).
effective_dosage: Not specified (lighting: 100% red or 75% red, 20% blue, 5% green; photoperiods: 17 h or 23 h).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of olive wastewater concentrates as a fertilizer for tomato plants, assessing their impact on yield and quality compared to traditional inorganic fertilizers.
results_summary: The study found that olive wastewater concentrates increased tomato yield without causing phytotoxic effects or negatively impacting fruit quality (pH, °Brix, sugars, organic acids) or bioactive content (phenolic compounds and carotenoids). The combined use with inorganic nitrogen also showed promise as a substitute for inorganic potassium.
population_specificity: Tomato plants in open field assays over three consecutive crops.
effective_dosage: Fertilization via drip irrigation every 15 days, totaling five treatments per crop.
study_duration: Three consecutive crop cycles (duration per cycle not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of compost inoculated with Clonostachys rosea f. catenula on tomato cultivation, focusing on compost quality, plant growth, and resistance to red spider mite infestations.
results_summary: The study found that compost from fungus-treated heaps induced 100% endophytic colonization in tomato plants and significantly enhanced seed germination, though it did not significantly reduce red spider mite infestations. The compost was non-toxic to tomato seeds and seedlings.
population_specificity: Tomato plants (Solanum lycopersicum) cultivated in composted cabbage waste.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antifungal effects of vanillin on gray mold and black rot in cherry tomato fruit and explore its mechanism of action.
results_summary: Vanillin significantly inhibited the growth and infection ability of Botrytis cinerea and Alternaria alternata, damaged pathogen membranes, and reduced pathogenicity-related enzyme activities, effectively preventing postharvest diseases in cherry tomatoes.
population_specificity: Cherry tomato fruit infected with Botrytis cinerea and Alternaria alternata.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of foliar selenium spray on selenium accumulation, fruit quality, and aroma profile in tomatoes at different developmental stages.
results_summary: Selenium accumulation in tomatoes was higher when applied at the flowering stage, with no significant difference between 1 and 1.5 mg Se L-1 concentrations. Se treatment improved aroma-related volatile compounds and reduced blossom-end rot without negatively affecting fruit quality.
population_specificity: Tomato plants (specifically fruit from the first and second trusses).
effective_dosage: 0, 1, and 1.5 mg Se L-1 applied at flowering and immature green stages.
study_duration: Not specified (assumed single application per stage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of ozonated water in inactivating viruses and bacteria on cherry tomatoes compared to water-only washes.
results_summary: Ozonated water achieved microbial reductions of 99 to 99.99%, but no statistically significant differences were found compared to water-only washes for tomatoes. A notable exception was observed with MNV and B. cereus on Boston bibb lettuce, but not on tomatoes.
population_specificity: Cherry tomatoes inoculated with viruses (MNV, MS2 bacteriophage) and bacteria (Enterobacter cloacae, Bacillus cereus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antifungal efficacy of low molecular weight chitosan compounds, alone and in combination with synthetic fungicides, against Botrytis cinerea in tomatoes.
results_summary: The study found that chitosan compounds, particularly when combined with synthetic fungicides like fludioxonil or difenoconazole, significantly reduced fungal growth and metabolic activity of B. cinerea. Treatment with chitosan-gallic acid conjugate reduced rotting in artificially inoculated tomato fruit by 83%.
population_specificity: Artificially inoculated tomato fruit (post-harvest).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of UVA/UVC pre-treatment and red-blue LED light on bioactive compounds and quality parameters in green tomatoes during refrigerated storage.
results_summary: LED light exposure increased total carotenoids (β-carotene and E-lycopene) up to threefold and antioxidant capacity by 30%, without affecting phenolic content or quality parameters. UV treatments alone did not significantly impact carotenoid levels.
population_specificity: Green tomatoes (Solanum lycopersicum L.) cultivar "Raf."
effective_dosage: UVA (366 nm) and UVC (254 nm) at 1 kJ/m²; red-blue LED light at 25.4 µmol/m²/s.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of pelargonic acid (PEL) emulsions in reducing Salmonella contamination on tomatoes and preventing cross-contamination, while also assessing its impact on tomato quality.
results_summary: PEL emulsions significantly reduced Salmonella contamination (1-6 log CFU/g reductions) compared to water-only or no rinse treatments, outperforming chlorine and peroxyacetic acid. However, PEL negatively affected tomato texture, requiring less force for skin penetration and compression compared to other treatments.
population_specificity: Tomatoes artificially contaminated with a five-serovar Salmonella enterica cocktail.
study_duration: Evaluated at 0 hours, 1 day, and 7 days post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health benefits of anthocyanin-rich tomatoes, focusing on their nutraceutical value and potential roles in disease prevention.
results_summary: The study found that anthocyanin-rich tomatoes exhibit higher antioxidant capacity and demonstrated health benefits in vitro and in vivo, including scavenging harmful reactive species, inhibiting cancer cell proliferation, and anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the lipid-lowering effects of a novel functional tomato sauce (OsteoCol) with a sterol-enriched yogurt in patients with polygenic hypercholesterolemia.
results_summary: The tomato sauce showed a significant LDL-cholesterol reduction (12% at high adherence), comparable to the sterol-enriched yogurt (15%), but low adherence in the tomato sauce group resulted in less effectiveness. The effect was more pronounced in participants with baseline LDL-cholesterol above 152 mg/dl.
population_specificity: 108 ambulatory patients with polygenic hypercholesterolemia (both genders).
effective_dosage: 150 ml/day of tomato sauce (OsteoCol) containing 3.5 mg carotenoids per gram.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare different methodological techniques for analyzing heat shock proteins (HSP) in tomatoes and evaluate their role in protecting against chilling injury.
results_summary: The study found that different electrophoretic and immunological techniques (SDS-PAGE, Western blot, etc.) could effectively analyze HSP response in tomatoes. Heat treatment induced HSP synthesis, which correlated with improved tolerance to chilling injury during storage.
population_specificity: Tomato fruits exposed to heat and anaerobic treatments.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exposure to 38°C for 0, 3, 20, and 27 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining anaerobic baffled reactor (ABR) effluent with commercial hydroponic fertilizer mix (CHFM) could improve tomato plant growth and yield in hydroponic systems.
results_summary: Tomato plants fed with CHFM or a 50:50 mix of ABR effluent and CHFM showed significantly better growth, biomass, fruit yield, and nutrient content compared to those grown with ABR effluent alone. The combination treatment also increased shoot levels of N, K, Ca, and Zn, indicating improved nutrient availability.
population_specificity: Tomato plants grown in a hydroponic system.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how exogenous salicylic acid (SA) application affects tomato plant physiology and its subsequent impact on mite digestive enzymes, energy reserves, and susceptibility to spirodiclofen.
results_summary: SA treatment increased enzymatic activity and certain plant defenses while reducing mite digestive enzyme activity and energy reserves. Mites on SA-treated plants showed higher mortality when exposed to spirodiclofen, indicating enhanced susceptibility.
population_specificity: Tomato plants (Solanum lycopersicum) and the spider mite Tetranychus urticae.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the osmotic dehydration (OD) process of tomatoes using alternative sweeteners to improve color retention and solid gain for candied products.
results_summary: The study found that osmotic dehydration improved tomato texture (firmness) and color changes were modeled effectively. Optimal results were achieved with oligofructose in the osmotic solution at shorter treatment times, validated by sensory analysis for organoleptic acceptance.
population_specificity: Tomatoes (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified (osmotic solution composition and concentration varied as part of optimization).
study_duration: Treatment duration varied as part of optimization (no fixed duration specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ultrasound combined with chemical agents (lactic acid, detergent, or silver nanoparticles) in decontaminating cherry tomatoes by reducing Salmonella Enteritidis levels.
results_summary: All treatments except detergent reduced Salmonella Enteritidis by more than one logarithmic cycle, with no significant difference in log CFU/g reduction between treatments. The combination of silver nanoparticles and ultrasound + lactic acid notably reduced bacterial counts to safe levels.
population_specificity: Cherry tomatoes contaminated with Salmonella Enteritidis.
effective_dosage: 1% lactic acid, 1% detergent, 6 mg/L silver nanoparticles, 200 mg/L sodium dichloroisocyanurate, ultrasound at 40 kHz for 5 min.
study_duration: Single treatment session (5 min for ultrasound).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a brief hot-water immersion treatment could reduce chilling injury symptoms in tomatoes by promoting antioxidant accumulation.
results_summary: Hot-water treatment at 52°C for 5 minutes significantly reduced chilling-associated decay and increased antioxidant content (lycopene, ascorbic acid, phenolics) but did not enhance sensory attributes or antioxidant capacity. It also reduced ripening time by 3 days in mature green tomatoes.
population_specificity: 'BHN-602' tomatoes at breaker turning (BT) and mature green (MG) stages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of a biobased compostable packaging (PLA trays and NatureFlex™ film) compared to traditional packaging (PET trays and PP Coex film) for fresh-cut cherry tomatoes, focusing on structural stability, mechanical properties, and the impact of sterilization treatments.
results_summary: The study found that the biobased compostable packaging demonstrated better properties for prolonging the shelf-life of fresh-cut cherry tomatoes, with UV sterilization enhancing these properties. UV treatment was less invasive compared to radiofrequency sterilization.
population_specificity: Fresh-cut cherry tomatoes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Trichoderma harzianum strain T22, biopolymer, and their combinations on crop performance, nutritional quality, and functional quality of greenhouse tomatoes.
results_summary: Treatments with T22, biopolymer, or their combinations significantly increased tomato yield (up to +40.1%) and lycopene content (up to +52%). They also enhanced levels of beneficial metabolites like asparagine, GABA, and MEA, suggesting improved plant metabolism and human health benefits.
population_specificity: Greenhouse tomato plants (Solanum lycopersicum L. cultivar Pixel).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the predatory mite Phytoseiulus persimilis and the acaricide bifenazate (Acramite) in controlling twospotted spider mites (TSSM) in staked tomatoes.
results_summary: The combination of P. persimilis + Acramite was the most effective treatment for reducing TSSM. P. persimilis established successfully but showed variable population growth and dispersal between years, while Acramite alone significantly reduced TSSM pressure in 2019.
population_specificity: Field-grown staked tomatoes in North Carolina.
study_duration: Two field experiments conducted in 2016 and 2019 (specific duration not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nematicidal activity of Bacillus firmus I-1582 against Meloidogyne luci in tomatoes and assess its plant growth-promoting effects.
results_summary: Bacillus firmus I-1582 reduced nematode counts by 51% and 53% in pot and microplot experiments, respectively, and demonstrated concurrent plant growth-promoting effects. Hyperspectral imaging successfully differentiated treated and untreated plants with high accuracy (97.4% and 96.3%).
population_specificity: Tomato plants infected with Meloidogyne luci.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the presence of heavy metals in tomatoes grown near a wastewater treatment plant and evaluate the associated health risks for human consumption.
results_summary: The study found elevated concentrations of heavy metals (Cu, Ni, Cr, Mn, Pb, Cd) in tomatoes, with roots accumulating the highest levels. Non-carcinogenic risks were highest for children, and Cr posed the highest carcinogenic risk via dietary intake.
population_specificity: Tomatoes grown in the discharge area of a municipal wastewater treatment plant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the FDA-EVIR microarray's ability to detect hepatitis A virus (HAV) and human norovirus in artificially inoculated fresh produce, including tomatoes.
results_summary: The study confirmed that FDA-EVIR can identify enteric viruses in tomatoes, with a detection limit of 1.0 × 10⁵ genome equivalents (ge) of HAV per array input when using total RNA extraction. The method was effective for both single and mixed viral species.
population_specificity: Artificially inoculated fresh produce (tomatoes, green onions, celery).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (virus inoculation levels: 1.0 × 10⁵ ge HAV for tomatoes, 1.2 × 10⁵ ge HAV for green onions, 1.0 × 10³ ge norovirus for celery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antimicrobial efficacy of a new nisin-based organic acid sanitizer (NOAS) against Salmonella on grape tomatoes, relative to chlorinated wash water.
results_summary: NOAS demonstrated significantly greater inactivation of Salmonella on tomatoes compared to chlorinated water, reducing bacterial populations to <1 CFU/g versus 4 CFU/g, respectively. The bioluminescence ATP assay correlated well with plate counts for untreated tomatoes but not for treated ones due to low bacterial levels.
population_specificity: Grape tomatoes inoculated with Salmonella.
study_duration: 5 minutes for tomatoes, 30 minutes for in vitro tests.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an advanced oxidation process combining gaseous ozone and aerosolized hydrogen peroxide in reducing Salmonella populations on tomatoes.
results_summary: The combination of gaseous ozone and aerosolized hydrogen peroxide significantly reduced Salmonella populations by up to 5.2 log CFU/fruit on smooth surfaces and 4.2 log CFU/fruit on stem scars, demonstrating synergistic effects compared to either treatment alone.
population_specificity: Grape tomatoes inoculated with Salmonella typhimurium.
effective_dosage: Gaseous ozone (800 and 1600 ppm) and aerosolized hydrogen peroxide (2.5%, 5%, and 10%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the antifungal activity of methanol extracts from five plants against Alternaria alternata in cherry tomatoes, both in vitro and in greenhouse conditions.
results_summary: Rosmarinus officinalis and Lavandula angustifolia extracts showed strong antifungal activity in vitro, inhibiting dictyospores production. In greenhouse tests, R. officinalis was the most effective, while L. angustifolia and Punica granatum provided complete cure post-infection, but Quercus suber and Eucalyptus globulus were ineffective.
population_specificity: Cherry tomato plants (greenhouse-grown) and Alternaria alternata cultures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of ultrasound combined with calcium lactate treatment on calcium permeation and firmness of cherry tomatoes.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasound combined with calcium lactate maintained firmness (31.45 N) and increased calcium content in cherry tomatoes, with optimal conditions at 15°C, 15 min, and 20 W/L. AFM analysis showed larger CSP and SSP pectin chains in treated fruit.
population_specificity: Cherry tomatoes
effective_dosage: 2% (w/v) calcium lactate, ultrasound at 20 W/L for 15 min

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant, anticancer, and anti-inflammatory properties of extracts from four tomato varieties, comparing tangerine and red tomatoes.
results_summary: Tangerine tomatoes showed lower IC50 values in anticancer and anti-inflammatory assays, indicating greater potency compared to red tomatoes, particularly the Olga's Round Golden Chicken Egg and Golden Green varieties.
population_specificity: In vitro (prostate cancer cell lines) and inflammatory pathway assays.
effective_dosage: Not specified (measured in mg dry tomato equivalent/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of ethanol treatment on the quality characteristics of cherry tomatoes during storage at room temperature.
results_summary: Ethanol treatment improved sensory quality, resulting in redder, softer fruits with higher levels of ascorbic acid, sucrose, fructose, and 6-methyl-5-hepten-2-one, while reducing levels of certain volatile compounds. Consumers preferred ethanol-treated cherry tomatoes over controls.
population_specificity: Cherry tomatoes stored at room temperature (25°C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a thymol and salicylic acid edible coating (SIMTSA) on inhibiting Rhizopus stolonifer and enhancing defense enzymes in postharvest tomatoes.
results_summary: SIMTSA damaged the cell membrane and mitochondrial functions of R. stolonifer, reduced citric acid content, and increased defense enzyme activities in tomatoes, suggesting potential as a preservation method.
population_specificity: Postharvest tomatoes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of gelatin-carboxymethyl cellulose (Gel-CMC) blend films in preserving cherry tomatoes and grapes by improving their shelf life and reducing weight loss and browning.
results_summary: The study found that Gel-CMC films significantly improved tensile strength, elongation at break, and antimicrobial properties, reducing weight loss by up to 50.41% and browning by 31.34% in cherry tomatoes over 14 days. The 25Gel:75CMC ratio showed the most pronounced effects.
population_specificity: Cherry tomatoes (Solanum lycopersicum var. cerasiforme) and grapes (Vitis vinifera).
effective_dosage: Gel-CMC blend ratios of 75:25, 50:50, and 25:75 (volume per volume).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of pulsed light (PL) combined with H2O2 or chlorine in decontaminating grape tomatoes and wash water from Salmonella.
results_summary: Combined PL-H2O2 treatment was as or more effective than chlorine washing in killing Salmonella on tomatoes and keeping wash water contamination below detectable levels, especially under turbid water conditions. Sample size did not negatively impact treatment efficacy.
population_specificity: Grape tomatoes artificially contaminated with Salmonella.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the specific active compound in Tongkat Ali responsible for its anti-protozoal effects and compare its apoptotic response to metronidazole across Blastocystis sp. subtypes.
results_summary: Tongkat Ali extract and its compound eurycomanone induced a high apoptotic rate and reduced viable cell count more effectively than metronidazole, suggesting potential as a standardized treatment for Blastocystis sp. infections.
population_specificity: In-vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Eurycoma longifolia (Tongkat Ali) combined with concurrent training on erectile function and testosterone levels in men with androgen deficiency of aging males (ADAM).
results_summary: The study found that Tongkat Ali supplementation (200 mg) combined with concurrent training significantly improved erectile function and increased total testosterone levels in men with ADAM, with the most significant results observed in the combined intervention group.
population_specificity: Men aged 47.38 ± 5.03 years with ADAM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the extent of adulteration in E. longifolia herbal medicinal products (HMPs) using DNA barcoding and HPLC analysis.
results_summary: DNA barcoding identified 37% of tested HMPs as authentic and 27% as adulterated, with ITS2 being the ideal marker. HPLC validation revealed discrepancies where some authentic samples lacked the expected bioactive compound (eurycomanone).
population_specificity: Herbal medicinal products (HMPs) containing Tongkat Ali.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cytotoxicity effect of Eurycoma longifolia (Tongkat Ali) leaf extracts and its potential anticancer mechanism against breast cancer cell lines (MDA-MB-231 and MCF-7).
results_summary: The unfermented freeze-dried leaf extract showed the highest toxicity against both breast cancer cell lines, inducing apoptosis via DNA fragmentation, cell cycle arrest, and activation of apoptotic proteins. The extract's efficacy was dose- and time-dependent, with varying apoptotic pathways observed in the two cell lines.
population_specificity: In vitro breast cancer cell lines (MDA-MB-231 and MCF-7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-protozoal activity of Tongkat Ali against Blastocystis sp. isolates and compare its efficacy to allopathic drugs.
results_summary: Tongkat Ali exhibited the highest anti-protozoal activity among the tested herbal extracts, with its ethyl acetate fraction showing 94.9-95.1% efficacy across Blastocystis sp. subtypes, comparable to Metronidazole. The study found Tongkat Ali had more uniform sensitivity across subtypes than allopathic drugs.
population_specificity: Blastocystis sp. isolates from human-derived stool samples (subtypes ST1, ST3, ST5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and potential pharmacological effects of Tongkat Ali through toxicological and subacute/subchronic exposure studies.
results_summary: The study found no adverse effects on body weight, hematology, or organ pathology, but noted significant improvements in blood clotting times, kidney function markers, and cholesterol levels, particularly in males. These changes were deemed beneficial pharmacological effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal models based on dosage and methodology).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the traditional uses, bioactive compounds, safety profile, and potential health benefits of Eurycoma longifolia (Tongkat Ali) to highlight its therapeutic potential and need for further research.
results_summary: The study found that Tongkat Ali has a wide range of traditional medicinal uses, including aphrodisiac effects, treatment of malaria, and management of various ailments. It contains numerous bioactive compounds, with quassinoids being predominant, and demonstrated low toxicity in acute studies, with no adverse effects on liver or renal function at normal doses.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing literature and traditional uses).
effective_dosage: Not specified (acute toxicity studies used 1500-3000 mg/kg in mice).
study_duration: Not specified (chronic use mentioned but no specific duration provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Tongkat Ali's ergogenic benefits, particularly its effects on testosterone levels and muscle strength in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that Tongkat Ali significantly increased total and free testosterone levels and improved muscle strength in both male and female seniors, though effects were more pronounced in men. Female seniors showed lower testosterone and muscle force compared to males post-treatment, likely due to reduced sex hormone-binding globulin.
population_specificity: Physically active male (n=13) and female (n=12) seniors aged 57-72 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the in vivo effects of Tongkat Ali on body and organ weight, functional sperm parameters, and testosterone concentration to assess its safety and efficacy for male infertility management.
results_summary: Tongkat Ali reduced body weight and omentum fat, increased testosterone concentration, and improved sperm parameters (concentration, motility, vitality, and mitochondrial membrane potential) without adverse effects on organ weights.
population_specificity: Male rats (n=42)
effective_dosage: 200 mg/kg BW (low dose) and 800 mg/kg BW (high dose)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of popular erectile dysfunction supplements, including Tongkat Ali, based on consumer reviews and available literature.
results_summary: The study found limited human studies on Tongkat Ali's efficacy for erectile dysfunction, with only 17% of human studies reporting improvement in ED. Customer reviews showed a significant decrease in reported benefits after filtering untrustworthy comments.
population_specificity: Consumers of erectile dysfunction supplements sold on Amazon.com.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a standardized water-soluble extract of Tongkat Ali could improve symptoms of late-onset hypogonadism (LOH) and increase serum testosterone levels in patients.
results_summary: Treatment with Tongkat Ali significantly improved Ageing Males' Symptoms (AMS) scores and serum testosterone concentrations, with 71.7% of patients showing no complaints on the AMS scale and 90.8% achieving normal testosterone levels after treatment.
population_specificity: 76 patients suffering from late-onset hypogonadism (LOH).
effective_dosage: 200 mg of standardized water-soluble Tongkat Ali extract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immediate clinical effects of tongue scraping on halitosis compared to antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (aPDT) and probiotics.
results_summary: Tongue scraping showed an immediate significant reduction in halitosis (p = 0.0006), comparable to aPDT, but no long-term bacterial reduction was observed. Probiotics had no significant effect on halitosis levels.
population_specificity: 52 participants aged 18-25 with halitosis (H2S ≥ 112 ppb).
effective_dosage: Not specified (standard tongue scraping procedure assumed).
study_duration: Immediate effects measured; follow-up at 7, 14, and 30 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on halitosis diagnosis, etiology, and treatment, including tongue scraping, over the past 30 years.
results_summary: The abstract mentions tongue scraping as one of the treatments for halitosis but does not provide specific results regarding its effectiveness compared to other treatments. The review discusses various treatments, including newer methods like photodynamic therapy, probiotics, and ozone.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population with halitosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of tongue scraping versus aPDT in reducing halitosis caused by H2S gas.
results_summary: Tongue scraping reduced H2S concentration but was less effective than aPDT, which achieved socially unnoticeable halitosis levels. The benefits of tongue scraping diminished after one week, while aPDT maintained lower H2S levels longer.
population_specificity: 40 participants divided into two groups (20 each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immediate and short-term (7-day) effectiveness of tongue scraping, alone and combined with antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (aPDT), in reducing halitosis.
results_summary: Tongue scraping showed an immediate reduction in halitosis, but the effect was not sustained after 7 days. The combination of tongue scraping and aPDT did not show a significant difference from baseline at the 7-day follow-up.
population_specificity: Forty-four UNINOVE students or employees diagnosed with halitosis (H2S ≥ 112 ppb).
effective_dosage: Not specified for tongue scraping alone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of tongue scraping on halitosis, periodontal parameters, and local cytokine response in gingivitis patients.
results_summary: Tongue scraping significantly improved volatile sulfur compound levels, organoleptic and tongue coating scores, and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β and IL-8) in gingival crevicular fluid compared to oral hygiene instructions alone.
population_specificity: 36 gingivitis patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of tongue scraping with antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (aPDT) and their combined use in reducing halitosis.
results_summary: The study compared tongue scraping alone, aPDT alone, and their combination for halitosis treatment. Results indicated that tongue scraping was effective, but the abstract does not provide specific comparative efficacy data.
population_specificity: 39 patients with halitosis, divided into three groups of 13 each.
effective_dosage: Not specified for tongue scraping (home use instructions provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different oral hygiene regimens, including tongue scraping, in reducing morning bad breath, plaque formation, and gingivitis in healthy young adults.
results_summary: The study found that tongue scraping combined with tooth brushing (Group 3) showed significant reduction in morning bad breath, second only to the combination of all interventions (Group 4). Group 3 also demonstrated notable improvements in oral health metrics.
population_specificity: 40 young adults aged 18-22 years residing in a nongovernmental organization in New Delhi.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved tongue scraping as part of oral hygiene regimen).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of dental treatment, including tongue scraping, in improving oral health and preventing respiratory tract infections in ICU patients.
results_summary: The study found that dental treatment, including tongue scraping, significantly improved oral hygiene (reduced OHI-S and GI scores) and prevented most respiratory tract infections in ICU patients compared to routine oral hygiene alone. No severe adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Adult ICU patients staying for 48 hours or more with poor baseline oral health.
effective_dosage: Dental treatment (including tongue scraping) provided 4-5 times per week.
study_duration: From January 2011 to August 2013 (specific intervention duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (aPDT) using a red LED on reducing halitosis and microbiological levels in tongue coating immediately and at follow-up intervals.
results_summary: The study evaluated aPDT's impact on halitosis and tongue coating microbiology, with measurements taken immediately after treatment and at 7, 14, and 30 days post-treatment. Results indicated a reduction in halitosis and microbial levels, though specific statistical outcomes are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 45 young adults diagnosed with halitosis.
effective_dosage: aPDT with 0.005% methylene blue and red LED (660 nm, four irradiation points, 90 s per point, power of 400 mW, 36 J per point, radiant exposure of 95 J/cm²).
study_duration: Treatment administered once, with follow-up at 7, 14, and 30 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of mechanical (tongue scraping) and chemical (chlorhexidine) oral hygiene methods, alone and combined with probiotics, on halitosis severity in children.
results_summary: Tongue scraping (Group B) did not show significant or stable improvements in halitosis scores compared to conventional oral hygiene alone (Group A). The most effective treatment was the combination of tongue scraping, chlorhexidine, and probiotics (Group D), which yielded significant and stable improvements.
population_specificity: 208 children with organoleptic test (OLT) scores of 2 or more.
study_duration: 3 months (with follow-ups at 1 week and 3 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of full-mouth disinfection versus conventional quadrant therapy for halitosis control, with an additional focus on the impact of daily tongue scraping.
results_summary: Halimeter evaluation showed greater reduction of sulfide gases after full-mouth therapy than conventional therapy, but organoleptic testing and tongue coating index showed no difference among treatment groups or with tongue scraping.
population_specificity: Patients with halitosis (n = 180, divided into two main groups and further subdivided).
effective_dosage: Daily tongue scraping (frequency specified, amount not detailed).
study_duration: 4 weeks (for conventional quadrant therapy; full-mouth therapy completed within 24 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether comprehensive dental care, including tongue scraping, could enhance oral antisepsis and reduce lower respiratory tract infections (LRTIs) in critically ill ICU patients.
results_summary: The study found that the experimental group receiving dental care (including tongue scraping) had a significantly lower LRTI incidence (8.7%) compared to the control group (18.1%). Ventilator-associated pneumonia rates were also lower in the experimental group, with no severe adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Critically ill adult patients staying at least 48 hours in a general ICU.
effective_dosage: Dental care (including tongue scraping) provided 4-5 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review diagnostic methods and evidence for interventions related to tonsillar halitosis, including the role of tongue scraping in ruling out oral halitosis.
results_summary: The study found that tongue scraping is useful as an initial treatment to rule out oral halitosis, but there was insufficient high-quality evidence to draw firm conclusions about its efficacy for tonsillar halitosis. Improved methodology and more accurate halitosis detection techniques were recommended.
population_specificity: Patients with halitosis, particularly those with suspected tonsillar etiology.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of tongue scraping combined with a zinc- and chlorhexidine-containing mouth rinse on volatile sulfur compounds (VSCs) in breath and tongue microbiota.
results_summary: Tongue scraping provided no beneficial effects on microbiota or VSC levels compared to the active rinse alone. The active rinse alone reduced bacterial counts and improved halitosis, but tongue scraping did not enhance these outcomes.
population_specificity: 21 periodontally healthy subjects with intra-oral halitosis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (active rinse contained zinc and chlorhexidine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a comprehensive oral care protocol (including tongue scraping) versus standard oral care (manual toothbrushing) in maintaining oral health in intubated neuroscience ICU patients.
results_summary: The comprehensive protocol (including tongue scraping) prevented significant deterioration in oral health during intubation and restored baseline status after extubation, outperforming manual toothbrushing alone. Four specific oral health categories (tongue, mucous membranes, gingiva, and teeth) showed no significant deterioration with the comprehensive protocol.
population_specificity: Intubated patients in a neuroscience ICU.
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency implied by protocol compliance exceeding 91%).
study_duration: From intubation until 48 hours after extubation (exact duration per patient not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of tongue scraping, both with and without an active mouth rinse, on intra-oral halitosis.
results_summary: Tongue scraping combined with an active mouth rinse significantly reduced organoleptic scores and volatile sulfur compounds, but did not provide additional benefits beyond the rinse alone. The inactive rinse with tongue scraping showed temporary reductions in halitosis markers.
population_specificity: 21 subjects without periodontitis, mean age 45.7 years (range: 21-66).
effective_dosage: Not specified for tongue scraping; mouth rinse contained zinc acetate (0.3%) and chlorhexidine diacetate (0.025%).
study_duration: Assessments were made immediately after, at 30 minutes, and at 14 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of mechanical tongue cleaning (scraping or brushing) compared to no mechanical tongue cleaning on breath odour and tongue coating.
results_summary: The review found that mechanical tongue cleaning, in addition to toothbrushing, positively impacted oral malodour parameters, though data on chronic halitosis were insufficient.
population_specificity: Humans in good general health, aged ≥17 years, with no systemic disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the presence of halitosis in MS patients compared to a control group and assess the effectiveness of tongue scraping combined with antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (aPDT) in treating halitosis.
results_summary: The study found that tongue scraping and aPDT were used to treat halitosis in patients, but specific efficacy results for tongue scraping alone were not detailed in the abstract.
